chapters.name: The relationship between personal tutoring and coaching

sections.subtitle: The relationship between personal tutoring and coaching

components.text: Sarah is a lecturer in the first year of her new post.

components.subtitle: Week 1
components.text: Sarah has been given the job of meeting a group of students in a tutorial session. She has been tasked with CV reviewing and researching empoyers, as well as developing their employability skills. She must work with each student individually and also set new SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic and Time-related) targets regularly. Her head of department has asked her if she could track and monitor the students' progress throughout and feedback on their progress to the rest of the teaching team during the weekly departmental meeting. Sarah has found that she has been contacting students on the phone a lot when some students have been late, absent and not meeting deadlines. She has found this work challenging, but rewarding.

components.subtitle: Week 2
components.text: In her second week, while delivering a class where the students are working in groups to develop presentations, Sarah finds that she has time to work with students individually to discuss their learning and progress. Paul, a student in the class, confides in her that he is finding that he cannot keep up with all the expectations of the course and that he feels anxious. Sarah allows Paul to express his concerns and questions him to find out whether he is actually behind with his course and what reasons he believes there are for this. As the conversation develops, it becomes clear to Sarah that Paul isn't actually too far behind with his work but that his recent unexpected poor exam results has knocked his confidence down. Sarah steers the conversation more towards Paul's strengths and enbales him to explore the potential actions he could take to regain his confidence and get 'back on track'. They agree some small steps for Paul to take and decide to review the outcome of Paul's actions in the class next week.

During her third week, Sarah has arranged to meet students regularly for one to ones. She explores with each student how they are feeling and encourages them to discuss what issues they are facing both within and outside of the college. Sarah asks questions and challenges students to think about and express their issues a bit more deeply than they might normally, whilst providing encouragement and guidance if needed. Her main aim is to give the students a change to look at themselves more closely, to explore new ideas and help build their confidence. She encourages the student to take the initiative and any actions resulting from the meeting that contribute to their learning and progress remains their responsibility. She helps them to think about potential outcomes of the actions in more detail and how long they think it would take for them to show progress. Sarah has found working with her students one to one is rewarding and a welcome change from regular class delivery. She has discovered that the students tend to behave differently than when in a normal classroom or corridor environment and that she is looking forward to this aspect of her role.
components.subtitle: Week 3

components.text: Having read through this case study of weekly interactions between personal tutor Sarah and students and, drawing on your own knowledge and experience, decide which aspect of the role they are describing, personal tutoring or coaching and state why.

list_elements.text: The principles of being an effective personal tutor are very similar, if not the same in most instances, as being an effective teacher.

What ‘success’ ultimately looks like for each student is very different because they all come from different backgrounds, have varying levels of skills and abilities and each face different challenges throughout their learning both within and outside the institution.
As teachers, we are increasingly expected to offer more to students’ overall success than just teaching good sessions.
There is a natural overlap between personal tutoring and coaching.
Four main approaches to helping a student can be identified: being directive or non-directive, focusing on their intellectual or emotional need.

chapters.name: Core values and skills of the personal tutor

components.subtitle: Among the core values of the personal tutor, the following ones are key:

list_elements.text: high expectations
approachability
diplomacy
being non-judgemental
compassion
the ‘equal partner, not superior’ approach
genuineness

components.text: To demand maximum effort and application from your students.

components.subtitle: Typical Context
components.text: The achievement of students is closely linked to the expectations you place on them. Students who are expected to learn more or perform better generally do so while those held to lower expectations usually achieve less.

Lowering expectations of students can become a self-fulfilling prophecy and the way to break this is to raise expectations for all areas of a student's life and to ensure they receive the support they need to reach those high expectations. This will positively affect their grades and job prospects, as well as value-added scores and the success rates of the institution.
The attribute of being seen as friendly, easy to talk to and discuss things with.

components.subtitle: Typical Context
components.text: As you start to work with students in one to ones, it can be obvious when something isn't quite right with them, either through verbal or non-verbal cues, for example, lack of eye contact, negative body language and/or demeanour.
Ways to appear more approachable to a student in order to encourage them to be more open are to:

list_elements.text: Have friendly body language, in other words, smile, have your arms open, not folded;
Not to be afraid to ask if everything is alright, using a general open questions, for example, 'how are you?', 'how are things?';
Reiterate that they can trust you ( obviously not to keep a secret if it might put them or someone else at risk of harm).

components.text: You should realise this can take time; students may not trust you straight away.
Using mediation and de-escalation between opposing views or 'sides' in order to positively progress.

components.subtitle: Typical Context
components.text: Instead of taking punitive action against students in terms of stating the possible negative outcomes of not engaging with others, showing good communication skills can sensitively and tactfully mediate the situation. Becoming skilled in the art of de-escalating a tense situation is a very useful way to be able to positively influence your students.
Not viewing or labelling a student as, for example, 'good' or 'bad'. In other words, you are making a conscious effort to avoid being critical of the actions of students and trying to be open-minded.

components.subtitle: Typical Context
components.text: It isn't easy to reserve judgement on a student and no practitioner, new or experienced, is entirely able to do so. However, the core value of being non-judgemental strives to overcome the labelling of students and in reality is always trying to give them the opportunity to show you their better side. It is important to say that, from experience, sometimes in this relationship, you will get your heart broken.

Some students will not always rise to the challenge; however, if we go back to the principles of being an effective personal tutor, it is about motivating and inspiring them to achieve their potential. In order for a student to achieve this and hopefully improve their behaviour or attitude, it is important to approach each of them with an open mind, as many times as you, the department or institution is able to do so.

sections.subtitle: The equal partner, not superior approach

components.text: Presenting yourself as on the same level as the student rather than being overly hierarchical.

components.subtitle: Typical Context
components.text: There are many opportunities to display to students that you understand what pressures they face and this approach also allows you to role model good behaviour and provide a positive attitude to stressful situations. Good parents try to instil positive core values into their children and the personal tutor can do the same when you role model core values to your students.
Understanding students' feelings and caring about their well-being.
Compassion means putting yourself 'in the shoes' of the student and taking action to ensure a positive outcome.
Showing your ture feelings and showing to your students that you truly care about their learning, progress and well-being.

components.subtitle: Typical Context
components.text: As a general rule, students are perceptive and can tell when a teacher is authentic in their concern for them. From experience, you will have greater success in helping students react in a more positive manner towards you if they feel that the help, advice and support you are providing is genuine and honest.

sections.subtitle: Domain general and domain specific skills

components.text: Domain-general are common skills which may not necessarily be directly related to your personal tutor role and which you would find useful for most jobs, for example, good communication, time- management, problem-solving and organisational skills. Domain-specific skills are those which are more directly related to your personal tutor role.

components.subtitle: ‘Hard’ and ‘soft’ skills
components.text:
A further way to divide the core skills is into ‘hard’
and ‘soft’ skills. Here are some examples for each category.

list_elements.text: Effective tutorial and lesson planning;
Developing a presentation or lesson resource;
Effective one to one meetings with learners;
Helping a learner develop their job application.
building rapport;
decision-making;
reflecting back and summarising;
active listening and questioning;

sections.subtitle: The core skills of the personal tutor

components.subtitle: Building genuine rapport with your students
components.text: Developing a harmonious relationship with a student in which each person is able to communicate effectively and understand each others' feelings or ideas.

components.subtitle: Active listening and questioning
components.text: Involves listening intently. It is important to be seen to be listening through verbal and non-verbal messages.

components.subtitle: Challenging
components.text: Using questions or statements to make the student think more carefully about his/her situation and challenge assumptions he/she may ne bamking. This may help the learner see things he/she may be failing to recognise.

components.subtitle: Reframing
components.text: Encouraging the student to see him or herself, others or issues from a different, or another person's, perpective. Often used in conjunction with challenging.

components.subtitle: Reflecting back and summarising
components.text: Showing the student that you understand the content, feeling and meaning of what they have said through an extension of active listening. This is usually achieved through paraphrasing back to the student what he/she has said.

components.subtitle: Teamwork
components.text: Working with fellow personal tutors to develop a tutorial programme of work.

components.subtitle: Decision-making and problem-solving
components.text: Thinking through and making difficult decisions, even when there doesn't appear to be a clear consensus or solution.

components.subtitle: Role modelling
components.text: Showing your positive core values through the daily actions you take. This shows your students what a good approach and behaviour looks like. This is where you 'walk the talk'.

components.subtitle: Proactivity, creativity and innovation
components.text: Trying out new ideas and approaches to constantly aim to improve your personal tutoring practice. In our experience, the most effective personal tutors are relentlessly proactive in seeking out and helping to address student issues.

components.subtitle: Working under pressure
components.text: Staying calm in order to stay effective. Whether it's deadlines, competing demands, difficult situations or complex student issues, this is something every practitioner grapples with at some time throughout the academic year.

list_elements.text: Rapport between practitioners and learners positively influences learner enjoyment of their subject, attendance, and time spent studying. (Benson et al, 2005)
Additionally, rapport has been linked to increased learner attention .(Buskist and Saville, 2004)

Intentionally building genuine rapport with learners has positive consequences on their learning, for example:
  • discussions flow more easily,
  • student engagement (within and outside the classroom) increases, as well as their motivation for doing well on their course.
Starcher (2011)

In his research, he intentionally tried to build rapport with learners through one to one meetings and found that 95 per cent of the learners believed the one to one meetings were useful and also reported that they felt more comfortable speaking out in class, asking him questions both inside and outside of the classroom and because of the one to one meetings they felt he was truly interested in them as individuals.Starcher (2011)

How often?

list_elements.text: a reasonable regularity needs maintaining for keeping momentum going and possible revisiting issues and reviewing progress.

components.text: Who is invited?

list_elements.text: a small group of your peers at work (group supervision) or a one to one with a peer or your manager ('paired' of 'individual' supervision);

In the case of the former, the line manager doesn't attend unless he is specifically invited. Some reasons for this:
  • To avoid the manager leading and, possibly even without knowing, driving an agenda and seeing themselves as there to 'solve' issues;
  • exploration of the issue is reduced;
  • participants will feel more free to express feelings they may have about an issue without a potential fear of looking 'weak' or 'not coping' in front of their manager;
  • supervision is differentiated from other typical group meetings.

components.text: What are the ground rules?

list_elements.text: use of a confidential space;
a specific amount of time is given;
one person to talk at a time;
clarity over whose issues will be aired that session; it may be that there is only 1 or 2 per session;
this lead contributor(s) to start the session outlining the issue along with their concerns/questions;
concentration on that issue and the contributor's concern and questions without digression from this or others bringing forward their concerns;
focus on open questions from the group enabling the lead contributor to find their own solutions.

There is a need for setting boundaries for the good and
protection of both students and yourself (as personal tutor).

There are different types of boundaries most relevant to the personal tutor and a rationale for each:
  • expertise – I need to use other ‘experts’ at times;
  • temporal – I am a limited resource;
  • behavioural – I can influence but not control learner behaviour;
  • peer - the promotion of respect and professionalism amongst my students.

Effective boundary setting can enable students to take
responsibility and become more independent.

and between themselves as peers?

examined in this section or similar boundaries?

(and your colleagues within it) place on setting
boundaries? What do you think could be done to

components.text: P63Work with students to identify, where appropriate, goals relating to their career development and suitable and realistic progression options.

components.subtitle: Relevant impact measure:
components.text: Internal progression rates for your student groups; analysis of destination data for your student groups.

list_elements.text: Institutional measuring
"You can’t fatten a pig by weighing it all the time"
Correlation and causation

Ways in which the two key elements of intellectual/academic
progress and emotional well-being of students can be
measured.

Ways of measuring the impact of your personal tutoring at
both an individual and institutional level.

Ways of being constructively critical of measuring the impact
of your personal tutor role

The National Occupational Standards for Personal Tutoring can
be linked to impact measures.

There is a  relationship between personal tutoring practice and
student performance, and a value in assessing the extent of
this, whilst acknowledging other multiple factors influence
learner performance.

To what extent do you think there is a focus on measuring the impact of personal tutor practice on students’ performance:
  • by you, individually?
  • by any teaching course you may have undertaken?
  • by your manager, at a team level, in your institution?
  • by senior managers across your institution?

If it is not carried out or covered, how could it
become so?

To what extent do learner-facing staff at your
institution perceive measuring impact of personal
tutoring as having a clear rationale and as
meaningful and developmental? What could be
done to improve this perception?
